Based on bug bounty reports from sources like HackerOne, Bugcrowd, and Synack, here are common account takeover methods:

1. Weak password resets: Predictable tokens, IDOR allowing unauthorized resets.
2. XSS: Inject scripts to change emails/passwords.
3. CSRF: Forge requests to modify account details.
4. OAuth/SSO flaws: Missing state params, open redirects.
5. Credential stuffing: Reusing leaked passwords.
6. Session issues: Fixation, weak JWTs.
7. Forgot password exploits: Token leaks, Host header injection.
8. IDOR: Direct access to user objects.
9. Default/weak creds: Unchanged defaults.
10. MFA bypass: Logic flaws in auth flows.

Always test ethically! (347 chars)

EIGEN, the native token of the EigenCloud ecosystem (previously EigenLayer), is revolutionizing decentralized security and computation on the Ethereum blockchain. Designed as a universal intersubjective work token, EIGEN enables secure validation of digital tasks that go beyond traditional on-chain verification. By addressing "intersubjectively attributable faults"â€”where multiple external observers agree on task performanceâ€”EIGEN expands the scope of blockchain security to support a wide range of decentralized applications (dApps), from DeFi platforms to cross-chain bridges and data availability solutions. With a current price of ~$1.27-$1.43 USD and a circulating supply of approximately 320-323 million tokens, EIGEN is making waves in the crypto space![](https://t.co/2VQYMOMoDv)[](https://t.co/i4LNT8bNdK)

Built on Ethereum, EigenCloud introduces the groundbreaking concept of **restaking**, allowing Ethereum stakers to reuse their staked ETH or Liquid Staking Tokens (LSTs) to secure additional decentralized services. This creates a pooled security model, reducing fragmentation in the ecosystem and enabling dApps to leverage Ethereumâ€™s robust security without building their own trust networks. Stakers can earn additional rewards by opting into EigenCloudâ€™s smart contracts, while operators validate Actively Validated Services (AVSs) like EigenDA, ensuring reliable data availability and scalable computation. protocol-neutral infrastructure on @anoma ğŸ§µ

most blockchains make you play by their rules:

Ethereum â†’ one big computer where every app squeezes in, and it is often congested.

Cosmos â†’ you build your own chain, and you also manage your own security.

Polkadot â†’ you build a chain { parachain }, but it must plug into the polkadot relay chain for security.

anoma is different.

itâ€™s protocol-neutral, and it doesnâ€™t force every app to use the same system. apps can bring their own rules and still run on the same network.

think of it like this â¤µï¸
Ethereum = one airline.
Cosmos = build your own airport.
Polkadot = one big hub where all airlines must dock.
anoma = an open airport where any plane can land,  private jets, and helicopters.

why this is a huge game changer 

developers arenâ€™t boxed in â†’ they decide how their app should work.

apps can talk to each other â†’ money, data, and actions flow smoothly without congestion.

apps can upgrade easily â†’ no chain migration, just update the rules on your terms.

less congestion â†’ resources are shared more fairly.

how it works â¤µï¸

it focuses on intents, it's what you want to do, not just transactions.

each app can run with its own logic.

apps link together like modules.

privacy is built in with zero-knowledge tech.

real-world impact
DeFi, gaming, governance, supply chains, and tokenized real-world assets can all run together with their own rules while sharing the same base network.

ğŸ‘‰ in a quick summary: anoma builds the roads first; apps bring the vehicles. any app, any protocol, can run, grow, and connect on equal footing.

Ritual Network and the Resonance Fee Market

One of the biggest pain points in blockchain today is how fees are handled. Traditional â€œgasâ€ models charge the same type of fee whether youâ€™re making a simple token transfer or verifying a complex zero-knowledge proof. 
Thatâ€™s like paying the same price to mail a postcard as you would to ship a car. It doesnâ€™t make sense, and it holds back innovation.

This is where @ritualnet Resonance Fee Market changes the game. Instead of treating all computation equally, Resonance is built on the principle that not all work has the same cost. Some tasks are light and quick, while others are heavy and resource-intensive. Resonance ensures fees reflect the true value of the work being done, so small tasks stay cheap while complex ones are priced fairly without breaking the system.

Ritual is designed for heterogeneous computation. Things like AI inference, zero-knowledge proof verification, and TEE execution. 
The Resonance Fee Market adapts to each of these workloads, making sure developers arenâ€™t unfairly penalized for building advanced applications on-chain.

What makes Resonance powerful is how seamless it feels for developers and users. Under the hood, itâ€™s complex economic design. On the surface, it just works. Fees stay reasonable, transactions run smoothly, and the network avoids the wild congestion spikes that plague older systems. By optimizing for both fairness and efficiency, Resonance keeps Ritualâ€™s ecosystem stable even under heavy demand.

Compared to traditional gas fees, this is a huge step forward. Gas models donâ€™t account for the diversity of workloads, so they are either unfair or inefficient. Resonance fixes this by aligning price with effort, like how electricity billing charges differently for charging your phone versus running an entire factory. It is simple, logical, and much more sustainable.

For developers, that means predictable fees and a clear path to scaling applications. For users, it means a smoother experience and costs that actually make sense. And for the Ritual Network as a whole, it means sustainable growth and a fairer foundation for computation.

And this isnâ€™t just theory. Economic simulations of the Resonance Fee Market show reduced volatility, greater efficiency, and a healthier balance across the ecosystem. Itâ€™s not about making fees cheaper for the sake of it, it is about making them smarter, fairer, and future-ready for the kinds of workloads Ritual is built to support.

A "Field Note" from my upcoming MAoS - Malware Analysis on Steroids book:

The industry has fooled many of us to think that malware analysis without reverse engineering is malware analysis, or what many classify it as â€œbasic malware analysisâ€. There is no such thing as basic malware analysis, but only proper malware analysis, which must employ some level of code reverse engineering.
Think of static and dynamic analysis as complimentary part to set the table for the good tasting food of reverse engineering. Remember, static and dynamic analysis without proper reverse engineering is, for me, like a tasteless piece of book. And why is that you ask?
Letâ€™s say you want to understand why a malware suddenly â€œcrashesâ€ or how exactly a malware parses a suspected JSON file downloaded from a remote C2 server. How would you know if the malware unexpectedly crashes from a bug or because of an Anti-VM technique?
How would you prove that a process actually loads a malicious JSON configuration into memory?
Only with a proper, deep reverse engineering you can do such things!
Period.

I think men are naturally more romantic than women. 

Sure women enjoy romance more, and anticipate it with more vulnerability, but they arenâ€™t themselves as romantic in their attitude and actions. 

Scientifically, research shows that men fall in love faster, fall out of love slower, and only initiate 20% of divorces. 
Socially, we know that most romantic interactions are initiated by the man, which is preferable to most women anyway. 
And logically we can just realize that most traditionally romantic gestures are things men do for women, and not the other way around. Men approach women, buy flowers, serenade, reserve and pay for dinner, open the door, pull out the chair, and they propose. 
Women are expected to do a lot of things too, and it takes great work, dedication and discipline to be a fine woman, but thereâ€™s very few traditionally romantic gestures that I am aware of that a woman does for a man. She bakes food, gives praise, and then generally just accepts a manâ€™s gestures with grace, humility and gratitude. 

Now if I met a woman that actually did all those things, I would marry her immediately, so again there is great value in what women do. The point of my post here is just that I find it strange that women are painted as the more romantic sex. I think romance is inherently a masculine trait, and that femininity is actually a response to romance. 

I think this is why women love romance novels and men are mostly unimpressed by them; women yearn to experience romance, while men yearn to express it. 
Most women are uncomfortable with giving a compliment to a man, and yet they dream of being complimented. Most men are uncomfortable being complimented, and yet they dream of complimenting a woman and being heard, acknowledged and given just the satisfaction of knowing it improved her day; not that compliments are a great indicator of romance but the social behavior is still there. 

So, tldr, men need to reclaim their roles as romantic, vulnerable partners, and women need to stfu and adopt more grace and humility.

Here's a brief on each tool:

Kali Linux: Debian-based OS for penetration testing and ethical hacking, with pre-configured security tools.

Burp Suite: Web app security testing software for manual testing and automated vulnerability scanning.

Wireshark: Open-source network protocol analyzer for capturing and inspecting traffic.

Nmap: Free utility for network discovery, host/service scanning, and security auditing.

Metasploit: Framework for penetration testing, vulnerability verification, and security assessments.

John the Ripper: Open-source tool for password cracking and auditing across various systems.

Before buying NFTs (like Persona), youâ€™ll need an OpenSea account linked to a crypto wallet.
Unlike normal online shops where items are shipped to an address, NFTs â€œliveâ€ on-chain and must connect directly to your wallet.

Hereâ€™s how to set it up 

Step 1: Navigate to https://t.co/VlPM6Xv7GE
Click â€œConnect Walletâ€ (upper right corner)

Step 2: Create your account using email (powered by Privy).
â†’ Enter your email
â†’ Check inbox â†’ enter code
â†’ Confirm & accept terms
â†’ Click Continue

Note: Email login not yet available on mobile app.

Step 3: Secure your account.
â†’ Items purchased = tied to this 
wallet/email.
â†’ Lose email access = lose wallet access.

Keep login info safe.

Step 4: Customize your profile.
â†’ Pick a username
â†’ Upload a PFP + banner
â†’ Add a short bio
This makes it easier for other collectors to recognize and connect with you.

Step 5: Explore and Collect.
â†’ Browse collections
â†’ Add favorites to your watchlist
â†’ When ready, buy or bid, directly tied to your wallet.
